description_english:
0. Self-introduction
-Various activities that I tried while living as a developer for 10 years
-Fruit of various activities

1. Why should you be famous
-Self-satisfaction and motivation
- interview
- Turnover
- Salary
- founded
-Saving a colleague
-Good influence on the industry


2. How can you become famous?
-Be active in the developer community
-Post a blog
-Sharing with open source
-Share knowledge with developer event presenters
-Host a developer event
-Doing various activities inside the company
-Manage your history

title_english: Growth of High School Developers Through Communities
title_your_language: ì»¤ë®¤ë‹ˆí‹°ë¥¼ í†µí•œ ê³ ë“±í•™ìƒ ê°œë°œìì˜ ì„±ì¥ê¸°
description_english:
Hello, I am Park Hyeon-sang, a high school student who wants to change the perception of the world into media and code.
The content to be presented at DevRel Asia 2020 is how I was able to grow with my dream of being **developer** from 4th grade. We will tell you how you studied programming languages â€‹â€‹through hard community activities. Currently, I dream of becoming a front-end developer, and I am studying front-end development through "React.js" and multimedia development in "WebRTC".
In the case of React.js, it is one of the front-end frameworks that are widely used in Korea.
However, in the case of "WebRTC", there are few materials in Korean, and there are not many communities to ask. In that case, I will introduce how I study and develop. Is not very much. I just want to show you how you are doing community activities and how you can study through community activities through presentations. It will be a good presentation for those who are studying the same field as me or who are in a different field but do not know how to do community activities.

The content to be presented at DevRel Asia 2020 is how I was able to grow with my dream of being **developer** from 4th grade. We will tell you how you studied programming languages â€‹â€‹through hard community activities. Currently, I dream of becoming a front-end developer, and I am studying front-end development through "React.js" and multimedia development in "WebRTC".
In the case of React.js, it is one of the front-end frameworks that are widely used in Korea.
However, in the case of "WebRTC", there are few materials in Korean, and there are not many communities to ask. In that case, I will introduce how I study and develop. Is not very much. description.indonesia:
Hello, I am Park Hyeon-sang, a high school student who wants to change the perception of the world into media and code.
The content to be presented at DevRel Asia 2020 is how I was able to grow with my dream of being **developer** from 4th grade. We will tell you how you studied programming languages â€‹â€‹through hard community activities. Currently, I dream of becoming a front-end developer, and I am studying front-end development through "React.js" and multimedia development in "WebRTC".
In the case of React.js, it is one of the front-end frameworks that are widely used in Korea.
However, in the case of "WebRTC", there are few materials in Korean, and there are not many communities to ask. In that case, I will introduce how I study and develop. Is not very much. I just want to show you how you are doing community activities and how you can study through community activities through presentations. It will be a good presentation for those who are studying the same field as me or who are in a different field but do not know how to do community activities.

description_english:
Elastic is creator and maintainer of Elasticsearch (Kibana, Logstash, Beats) which is known an open source search engine. Elastic is also doing business and making commercial products on top of it's open source products. Being employee of the company and member of community at the same time, sometimes it makes dilemma between helping open source users and encouraging company business.

In this talke, I would like to share my last 5 years Elastic Seoul community experience, how Elastic's business and community's interest are changed, and what decisions I made in these timeline. (Everything is my personal choice and there  is no silver bullet answer.)

description.english:
Elastic is creator and maintainer of Elasticsearch (Kibana, Logstash, Beats) which is known an open source search engine. Elastic is also doing business and making commercial products on top of it's open source products. Being employee of the company and member of community at the same time, sometimes it makes dilemma between helping open source users and encouraging company business.

In this talke, I would like to share my last 5 years Elastic Seoul community experience, how Elastic's business and community's interest are changed, and what decisions I made in these timeline. (Everything is my personal choice and there  is no silver bullet answer.)

description_english:
### It tells about the journey from junior who didn't know anything to becoming a hero.

## From Zero to Hero

### What is AWS Hero ?

- Amazon Web Service Hero program 

### How to be hero ??

#### growth as an engineer.

- I meet DevOps

#### Community : AWSKRUG, DevOps Korea, with AWS Korea, Presentation. 

- The first presentation why i did
- Sharing

####  Opensource project : DevopsArtFactory https://github.com/DevopsArtFactory

- My Goal as an engineer : To artist From technition How to be ??

title_english: My Open-Source Project Lifecyle with Developer Communities
description_english:
Iâ€™ve been running many open-source projects as an owner or maintainer. Open-source projects are alive as long as they are supported by developer communities. One of my open-source projects was recently transferred to a big tech company because it would fill the missing gap that their services were lacking. With discussions going back and forth, I agreed to transfer it to the company.

As an open-source project maintainer, Iâ€™d like to talk about:

My journey towards the open-source contribution,
How this transfer means to the dev communities, and
How the project will be going in the future.
speaker: true

description_english: Developer Relations is still a fairly new field and if you talk to five different companies, you'll have five different answers on what DevRel is and how they approach it. In this talk, I want to cover the inverse. Let's talk about what Developer Relations and DevRel Professionals are NOT! This talk will examine the central tenants of Developer Relations and how these can lead to misconceptions about what DevRel Professionals do and their overall goals. The goal of the talk is to provide a clearer picture for both DevRel professionals and non-DevRel folks by focusing on what DevRel isn't.
speaker: true

description_english:
Why do you start a DevRel Program? Where do you even begin? And how to do it all, especially in times of Corona.

All these and more, I'll tell you all you need to know if you want to start a DevRel Program from the ground up. We'll go through a checklist of things you can possibly do and I'll share my framework for prioritizing that for a community and product.
speaker: true

title_english: Youâ€™re the First DevRel at Your Company, Now What?
description_english:
You're hired as the first Developer Relations employee at your company. You have many goals to achieve, but also have very few resources. What will you do?

Weâ€™ll talk about tips for success when starting your DevRel career, the challenges of the career change, and growing your team.
speaker: true
